name: Abidjan
fun_fact: Fun fact: Abidjan is called the 'Paris of West Africa' for its French colonial architecture and boulevards. It's also the world's largest French-speaking city after Paris - and produces 40% of the world's cocoa (your chocolate probably came from here)!

hero_dishes.description: Fermented cassava couscous with grilled tilapia or braised fish and spicy pepper sauce

hero_dishes.name: Alloco
hero_dishes.description: Fried ripe plantains served with spicy tomato-onion sauce and sometimes boiled eggs
hero_dishes.origin_story: The ultimate Ivorian street food - sweet plantains fried crispy with fiery sauce
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors, Allocodrome district (named after alloco!)

hero_dishes.name: Kedjenou
hero_dishes.description: Chicken or guinea fowl slow-cooked in a sealed pot with vegetables, no water added
hero_dishes.origin_story: From the B√©t√© people - the pot is sealed so the meat cooks in its own juices

signature_drinks.name: Bangui (Palm Wine)
signature_drinks.description: Fresh or fermented palm sap, milky white and slightly effervescent
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At maquis and palm wine bars - fresh is sweet, fermented is stronger

signature_drinks.name: Bissap
signature_drinks.description: Deep red hibiscus flower drink, sweetened and refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Cold from vendors, at restaurants - essential in the tropical heat

food_culture_notes: Maquis are open-air restaurants with grilled meat and cold beer - essential nightlife
Allocodrome in Cocody is the famous street food district
Eating is communal - sharing from central plates is normal
French influence means excellent baguettes and pastries too
